tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating the time for amplitude decay given eigenvalues, which is a numerical calculation. It involves understanding the relationship between eigenvalues and damping ratio, and then applying the formula for time to half amplitude. It involves multiple steps but doesn't require deep conceptual understanding or derivation.

answer_validation.reasoning: The given eigenvalue is $\lambda = -0.039 \pm 0.0567i$. The real part $\sigma = 0.039$ (positive, since $\lambda = -\sigma \pm j\omega$) is the decay constant. For an oscillatory mode, amplitude decays as $e^{-\sigma t}$. Setting $e^{-\sigma t} = 1/2$ gives half-life $t_{1/2} = \ln(2)/\sigma$. With $\ln(2) \approx 0.693147$ and $\sigma = 0.039$, $t_{1/2} \approx 17.7729$ s, rounding to 1 decimal gives 17.8 s, within the official answer range 17.7-17.9 s.

step_by_step: Step 1: Identify the given eigenvalue: $\lambda = -0.039 \pm 0.0567i$. This represents a damped oscillatory mode (complex conjugate pair).
Step 2: Extract the real part (decay rate). Write $\lambda = -\sigma \pm j\omega$, so $\sigma = 0.039$ (positive) and $\omega = 0.0567$ rad/s.
Step 3: Recall that for a linear system, the response amplitude due to this mode decays exponentially as $A(t) = A_0 e^{-\sigma t}$, where $A_0$ is initial amplitude.
Step 4: Set up the condition for amplitude to halve: $e^{-\sigma t} = 1/2$.
Step 7: Round to one decimal place: $17.8$ s.
formulas_used: $A(t) = A_0 e^{\Re(\lambda) t} = A_0 e^{-\sigma t}$ (amplitude envelope)

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the imaginary part (ω) in the half-life calculation
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusing frequency with damping rate, or misremembering formula.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: decay depends only on the real part (σ). Half-life formula involves only σ.
common_mistakes.consequence: Get answer ~12.22 s (using ln(2)/ω) instead of ~17.8 s.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to take the absolute value of the real part; using λ_real = -0.039 directly in formula, leading to negative time
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Not interpreting the sign correctly: decay requires positive σ.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recognize that for a stable mode, eigenvalue has negative real part, but decay constant σ is positive (λ = -σ ± jω).

common_mistakes.mistake: Mistaking half-life for time constant (τ = 1/σ) or doubling time
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusing different time measures in exponential decay.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall: half-life t_{1/2} = ln(2)/σ; time constant τ = 1/σ (time to decay to 1/e).

common_mistakes.mistake: Rounding ln(2) too crudely (e.g., using 0.69 or 0.7) leading to small error
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Use precise value 0.693147 or at least 0.693; keep more digits during calculation.
common_mistakes.consequence: Answer maybe 17.7 or 17.9, still within range but less accurate.

flashcards.back: σ = 0.039 (the positive value, since λ = -σ ± jω).

flashcards.front: Does the imaginary part of eigenvalue affect the half-life of amplitude decay?
flashcards.back: No. The half-life depends only on the real part (decay constant σ). The imaginary part affects oscillation frequency.

real_world_context.application: Aircraft certification: Handling qualities specifications (e.g., MIL-STD-1797) often require the phugoid mode to have a minimum damping ratio or maximum time to double/half amplitude.
real_world_context.industry_example: For a Level 1 flying quality (best), the phugoid mode should have a time to double amplitude of at least 55 seconds (or time to half amplitude less than a certain value for damped phugoid).
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Pilots should not be bothered by slowly decaying or divergent oscillations; adequate damping ensures safety and reduced workload.

real_world_context.why_it_matters: Ensures aircraft meets design stability margins before delivery.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quick 2-minute calculation: Identify σ, apply t = ln(2)/σ, compute carefully.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, compute 0.7/0.04 = 17.5, so answer near 17.5-18.0.
exam_strategy.time_management: Spend no more than 3 minutes; it's a straightforward 2-mark numerical.

alternative_methods.name: Using damping ratio and natural frequency
alternative_methods.description: From eigenvalue λ = σ ± jω, compute natural frequency ω_n = √(σ²+ω²) and damping ratio ζ = σ/ω_n. Then half-life can be found via t_{1/2} = ln(2)/(ζ ω_n).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: More steps but connects to standard second-order system parameters. Useful if ζ is needed for other purposes.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When problem asks for damping ratio or natural frequency as well.

response_json.question_text: For a general aviation airplane, one of the complex conjugate pair of eigenvalues for longitudinal dynamics is given by -0.039 +/- 0.0567 i (in SI units). If the system is disturbed to excite only this mode, the time taken for the amplitude of response to become half in magnitude is _______ s (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
